newsitem.title: UK: QUIET BRADY MARKET LOOKS FOR CLUES IN TREASURIES.
newsitem.headline: QUIET BRADY MARKET LOOKS FOR CLUES IN TREASURIES.

text.p: Trade in emerging market debt was sluggish on Tuesday, with the market looking for direction in the U.S. Treasury market.
"Turnover is low and the market is very dealer driven," a Brady bond trader at a European bank said.
"It looks as if the market will remain like this for the near future. It is trading in a tight range and looking for clues elsewhere."

Attention was focused on Wednesday's U.S. July retail sales. These are expected to be strong after a second quarter lull. A Reuter poll of economists forecast a rise of 0.7 percent in the headline retail sales and 0.5 percent ex-autos.
At 1400 GMT on Tuesday second quarter U.S. productivity and unit labour cost figures will be released.
"Treasuries have gained a little overnight, and we expect Bradys to track these gains and any other moves this week," a trader at a U.S. bank said.

Russian MinFins had firmed slightly on the back of local buying, traders said, especially series six and seven. MinFin 6 were up 0.375 points to 58.875 cents on the bid. MinFin 7 were up the same amount to 47.125 cents.
Meanwhile, the $16 billion Thai rescue package from the International Monetary Fund and Asian nations was not expected to boost emerging market debt prices but was met with relief by the market.
"Investors were concerned with what might go wrong with Thailand, and the effects that would have had on other emerging economies," an analyst at a European bank said.
"Now that it looks as if Thailand might be stabilised it has put the whole sector on a more secure footing. This has not led to higher prices, but just a more relaxed tone to the market," he said.

Thailand still has to commit to the full IMF package and the tough fiscal measures it will demand. The Thai cabinet will review details on August 19. -- Aline van Duyn, London Newsroom +44 171 542 7718
